8. I do not counsel against much study
in learning to make all varieties of kinds
of Cloth from life; there was no end to this
for Lucas, as anyone has attested
who knew this man of wide renown.
Yet Cloth –more than foliage, hair, or beards–
is a quest of ingenuity, an exploration of design
in graceful arranging, gathering, and binding.
right-middleDifferent kinds of Fabric, from life.
right-middleCloth more a matter of imagination than foliage or hair.

9. A drape should not be shortened to hang
to the loins, nor should it fall unevenly.
Pay attention to the way folds tighten and protrude,
move in and out, dissolve, appear foreshortened
according to their nature.
And here, do not forget the seven directions
or movements which I have mentioned elsewhere,
which will help us understand how much to gather.

10. Above all, to know where the limbs
of the Body fold or bend, when leaning forward,
where the thighs are attached to the pelvis;
likewise when kneeling, the folds of the ham,
armpits, elbows and other parts;
there, freely gather your Fabric into folds,
But let it stretch tightly across the lap
Between the knees, which are spread wide.
right-middleWhere the cloth must fold and crease.

11. For anything that is round and protruding,
that is, shoulders, thighs, knees, belly, calves, or buttocks,
there one should let [the cloth] rise up and round.
Do not add folds there, for the light surfaces
permit no strong contrast of a dark tone;
next to it, in the shadow, it will do no harm.
If you add many wrinkles, bunching or pinching
the material, no one will disapprove.
right-middleWhere the body or limbs have volume, avoiding folds, but instead letting [the cloth] lie flat, to prevent contrast in the illuminated places.

p043r_6
12. Just like branches on a Tree,
let your folds grow out of one another.
Avoid pocket folds, so that when unfolding
the Cloth, pockets would not be found
if they are made to stretch out or stiffen.
And make it so that one always can see
where your folds or gathers begin and end,
just as one sees in life.
right-middleAvoiding pocket folds. right-middleThe beginning and end of folds.
